Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1903

(Throughout the Questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is not Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1924, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the Questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
MEETING VISITORS, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? (4) At least 2-3

How many of these were bachelor's homes? (4) At least 2-3

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors? Twice or three times a year

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Mondays and Wednesdays

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Yes, frequently

What time of the day did you go, in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Afternoon

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (That is, was the term to "take refreshment" used, or was some other phrase more common?) We were asked to do so

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Lunch, sandwiches, etc.

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "cook after the places"? Usually someone else cooked

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Yes, often

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred. The main thing might have been housework.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, visits, drives or dances in homes? Describe, etc., please.

Were these more frequent in later years? Yes, after 1914

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, every two weeks, once a month, etc.? No

School

You will see that our school house was not built until 1918.

I taught my boys at home until 1918. They were 8 years old and could drive the pony and take Harry and Emma with him to the Handwerk school, which was 5 miles west. In 1917 we went to 1918 County school with them.

Though they had a covered buggy they were sometimes very hot and cold. They did not get to school in the very coldest of winter—until we got our own school in 1918.
School

You will see that our school house was not built until 1918.

I taught my boys at home until 1918. By then Paul was 8 years old and could drive the pony and take Harry and Ernest with him to the Homestead school, which was 5 miles nearest ours. In 1917 and part of 1918 Cousin Albert went with them though they had a hard trip. They were sometimes very hot and cold. They did not get to school in the very coldest winter—until we got our own school in 1918.
